children.value: The root element of the page, if it is an
The value of the primary language subtag (characters before the first dash) for the
attributes to match exactly. This is not known to impact accessibility, which is why it is permitted in this rule.
Although there is no known way that an inappropriate secondary subtag in the
attribute (such as "en-XYZ") can lead to accessibility issues, it is conceivable that with specific assistive technologies on some languages, there can be exceptions. In that case
Since most assistive technologies will consistently use

when both are used, violation of this rule may not necessarily be a violation of WCAG 2. Only when there are inconsistencies between assistive technologies, as to which attribute is used to determine the language, does this lead to a violation of SC 3.1.1.
<html lang="en" xml:lang="en"></html>

<html lang="en" xml:lang="en-GB"></html>
element with varied values but matching primary sub-tag value for
<html lang="en-GB" xml:lang="en"></html>
element with varied values but matching primary sub-tag value for
<html lang="en-XYZ" xml:lang="en"></html>
<html lang="fr" xml:lang="en"></html>
element is not applicable for this rule.
